raw_response: {"answer_index": 1, "answer_text": "Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "This 31-year-old woman presents with classic features of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD): 1) Bilateral palpable flank masses (enlarged kidneys), 2) Recurrent UTIs (common complication), 3) Hypertension (150/88 mmHg - common early manifestation), 4) Elevated creatinine indicating renal impairment, and 5) Bilateral enlarged kidneys with multiple anechoic (cystic) masses on ultrasound. ADPKD typically presents in the 3rd-4th decade of life. Autosomal recessive PKD presents in infancy/childhood. Medullary sponge kidney causes medullary cysts, not the large parenchymal cysts described here. Obstructive cystic dysplasia is typically unilateral and congenital."}
